CASE 72:
PROVISION OF FUTILE TREATMENT
Mrs Hauser is a 48-year-old woman with metastatic breast cancer that has spread to her
brain, despite numerous treatments over years. She is currently an inpatient at a private
hospital, having rapidly deteriorated over the last few weeks. She is now bedbound, requires
a feeding tube as she can no longer swallow safely and is finding it difficult to communi-
cate, although she can understand information given to her and clearly indicate her wishes.
Mrs Hauser is receiving high-energy nutritional supplements down her feeding tube at her
request, even though her body is no longer able to gain energy or nutrition from them due to
her advanced disease. She is likely to die within the next few weeks. Mrs Hauser is supported
by her husband and three teenage children. The entire family has actively and aggressively
pursued all treatment options, switching oncologists to gain access to experimental treat-
ments, some of which are not routinely available in Britain.
Mrs Hauser has repeatedly requested all possible interventions and treatments. Driven not
just by a desire to keep living, she has expressed a strong need to prove to her children that
she will never give up fighting the cancer, equating giving up with abandoning her family.
Mrs Hauser has regularly declined offers of psychological support. She has previously given
fully informed consent to risky treatments which did not have a strong body of evidence that
they would provide a benefit and accepted significant side effects throughout her treatments.
Mrs Hauser had been scheduled for her next chemotherapy in one week’s time and both she
and her husband are insistent it goes ahead, despite the most recent deterioration. The oncol-
ogist thinks it unlikely that the chemotherapy will provide any benefit, although he cannot
categorically say it will not keep Mrs Hauser alive for extra hours or days. He is aware she
had severe nausea the last time she had this chemotherapy and there is a risk it could actually
make her more unwell and hasten her death, as it can be damaging to the liver.
Questions
• Is this ‘futile’ treatment?
• Is it legal or ethical to provide or even offer treatment, purely for psychological
benefit, rather than physical benefit?
• Is there a difference between giving the high-energy supplements and the chemo-
therapy if both are purely for psychological benefit?

data.vignette: A 48-year-old woman with metastatic breast cancer and brain metastases has declined rapidly over weeks. She is bedbound and fed by tube because she cannot swallow safely. Her speech is limited, but she follows conversation and can reliably indicate yes or no. She is scheduled to receive another round of chemotherapy within days. She and her husband insist on proceeding, saying it matters to her to “keep fighting” for her teenage children. The oncologist doubts the treatment will meaningfully change the course of her illness. The last cycle caused severe nausea, and her liver function is now fragile, so the infusion could worsen her suffering or shorten her remaining time. If it is not ordered today, it cannot be prepared in time. Hospital policy and state law permit either giving chemotherapy or declining it as nonbeneficial in this setting.
data.choice_2: Do not give chemotherapy and transition to comfort-focused care.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove/soften language that makes withholding chemotherapy the medically correct option. Edit “The oncologist doubts the treatment will meaningfully change the course of her illness” to something like “The oncologist is uncertain whether another cycle will provide meaningful tumor control or symptom relief given her recent decline.” Replace “could worsen her suffering or shorten her remaining time” with “carries a high risk of significant toxicity and could worsen her quality of life.” Avoid labeling the choice as “nonbeneficial” in the narrative; instead frame it as a value-laden judgment about proportionality of benefit vs burden.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Make both options clinically/ethically defensible by adding a credible potential benefit to chemotherapy and clarifying uncertainty. For example: (1) note she had prior partial response or symptom improvement with this regimen; (2) state there is a small but real chance of temporary neurologic stabilization or reduced tumor-related symptoms, though benefit is uncertain; (3) clarify that her current decline may be from reversible factors (e.g., medication effect, infection treated, steroids started) so prognosis is not fully certain. Also balance the comfort-care pathway by acknowledging it could conflict with her expressed goals and may feel like abandonment to her/family, not simply the ‘safer’ default.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the vignette so that administering chemotherapy is not framed as clearly medically futile. Replace or soften language like “doubts the treatment will meaningfully change the course of her illness” and “could worsen her suffering or shorten her remaining time” with more clinically defensible uncertainty (e.g., prior modest tumor response, small chance of stabilizing neurologic decline or buying time for a milestone) while keeping real toxicity risk. Add a concrete moral cost to withholding (e.g., likely faster progression with worsening headaches/seizures or distress from abandoning a deeply held goal), and add a concrete moral cost to giving (e.g., high likelihood of hospitalization, delirium, loss of remaining time at home). Clarify capacity: either state she has decision-making capacity despite limited speech, or make it explicit that capacity is borderline and the husband is interpreting her wishes—so either option has ethical cost. Remove the legal/policy sentence unless it is needed as the forcing mechanism, since it can make the decision feel administratively “permitted” rather than ethically contested.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove value-laden phrasing that frames one option as admirable or the other as futile. Replace “keep fighting” with neutral wording such as “pursue further disease-directed therapy” or quote it once then add a neutral paraphrase. Rephrase “The oncologist doubts the treatment will meaningfully change the course” to balanced uncertainty (e.g., “The oncologist believes benefit is uncertain and may be limited”). Remove/soften “shorten her remaining time” (implies clear harm) to “could hasten clinical decline” or “could worsen symptoms without clear benefit.”

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Clarify decision-making capacity and who is the decision-maker: state whether she has capacity for this decision (understands, appreciates, can communicate) despite limited speech, or whether her husband is acting as surrogate. Specify the planned regimen line (e.g., “planned third-line systemic therapy”) without extra narrative. Consider removing redundant details (“declined rapidly over weeks” plus “bedbound”) or tie them to performance status (e.g., ECOG 4).

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Keep both choices parallel and purely action-oriented, ~10–15 words each, without adding a second major action. For example: Choice 1: “Proceed with the scheduled chemotherapy infusion as planned.” Choice 2: “Decline further chemotherapy and continue current supportive measures.” If you want hospice/comfort-care escalation, move details into vignette and keep choice as “Recommend no further chemotherapy.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Rebalance framing so chemotherapy is not portrayed as clearly futile and harmful. Remove or soften language like “doubts the treatment will meaningfully change the course” and “could shorten her remaining time,” or add countervailing facts that make benefit plausible (e.g., prior objective response to this regimen, symptom relief last cycle despite nausea, a biomarker-targeted agent with potential for meaningful tumor control, recent imaging showing some chemo-sensitive disease). Also add concrete moral costs to the no-chemo path beyond ‘comfort’ (e.g., patient experiences stopping as abandoning her role as a parent; family conflict; risk of losing trust; existential distress), and add concrete moral costs to giving chemo beyond general toxicity (e.g., may require ICU transfer for complications; may preclude being awake/present with children due to antiemetics/sedation; may prolong a dying process in a way she previously said she feared). Ensure each option both promotes and violates at least one ethical consideration without one looking like the medically correct choice.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close obvious middle options. Explicitly rule out (1) delaying a few days to reassess, (2) a dose-reduced or alternative ‘gentler’ regimen, (3) a time-limited trial with predefined stopping rules, and (4) concurrent chemo plus palliative/hospice involvement. For example: state that the chemotherapy is a single pre-mixed investigational/compounded dose that cannot be adjusted once prepared; the oncology service must either sign today to proceed as scheduled or cancel entirely; no alternative systemic therapy is available in the required time window; and the patient will likely lose capacity within days (or be transferred) so the decision cannot be deferred.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: As written, common oncology standards strongly discourage cytotoxic chemotherapy in a bedbound patient with rapidly progressive metastatic disease and poor performance status, making ‘do not give chemo’ look guideline-concordant. Add why guidelines/professional norms do not clearly settle it: e.g., this is a targeted agent with relatively lower symptom burden; she previously had meaningful tumor shrinkage and functional improvement on the same regimen; there is a specific, time-sensitive possibility of reversing a neurologic deficit from edema-related mass effect if tumor responds; or multiple consultants disagree on whether she meets ‘nonbeneficial’ criteria. Alternatively, explicitly state that institutional guidance is intentionally permissive here (no defined performance-status cutoff, allows clinician discretion when patient retains decision-making capacity), and that palliative care and oncology disagree, underscoring the gray zone.

data.vignette: A 48-year-old woman with metastatic breast cancer and brain metastases has become bedbound and receives tube feeds after recent neurologic decline. She can no longer speak full sentences, but on exam she consistently answers yes/no, understands the plan, and demonstrates decision-making capacity. She is due for an inpatient chemotherapy infusion in 48 hours. Two months ago, the same regimen led to temporary tumor shrinkage and fewer headaches, and she hopes another cycle could stabilize symptoms long enough to spend time with her teenage children. The last cycle caused severe nausea and confusion, and her liver tests are now borderline, raising concern for serious toxicity, hospitalization, or sedation that could limit her remaining alert time. The drug is compounded off-site in a fixed dose and must be authorized today; it cannot be delayed, modified, or replaced in time. Palliative care is already involved either way. Hospital policy and state law allow either proceeding or canceling in this setting.
data.choice_1: Proceed with the scheduled chemotherapy infusion.
data.choice_2: Cancel chemotherapy and continue symptom-focused care only.

choice_1.choice: Proceed with the scheduled chemotherapy infusion.

choice_2.choice: Cancel chemotherapy and continue symptom-focused care only.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause stating the patient explicitly requests the infusion today (e.g., "She clearly indicates she wants to proceed with chemotherapy despite the risks") and explicitly declines a comfort-only plan (e.g., "She says she does not want to cancel the infusion").

Add one clause quantifying the expected benefit likelihood (e.g., “oncology estimates <10% chance of meaningful symptom stabilization”) and one clause noting expected burden if chemo is forgone (e.g., “without chemo, headaches/neurologic decline are expected to worsen within weeks despite steroids/opioids”).

Add a clause stating that canceling chemotherapy is expected to lead to rapid worsening of headaches/neurologic symptoms (e.g., seizures, delirium) and increased suffering within days to weeks, so omission also carries foreseeable harm.

Add an explicit justice-relevant resource constraint (e.g., 'the infusion center has only one remaining chemotherapy slot/drug supply this week, and authorizing her dose would displace another patient with curable disease' or 'the patient is uninsured and the hospital would absorb a very high cost').

data.vignette: A 48-year-old woman with metastatic breast cancer and brain metastases is bedbound and receives tube feeds after recent neurologic decline. She cannot speak full sentences. She consistently answers yes/no. She understands the plan and demonstrates decision-making capacity. She is due for an inpatient chemotherapy infusion in 48 hours. She clearly indicates today that she wants to proceed and does not want to switch to a comfort-only plan. Two months ago, the same regimen led to temporary tumor shrinkage and fewer headaches. Oncology advises that any further symptom stabilization is uncertain and likely limited. The last cycle caused severe nausea and confusion, and her liver tests are now borderline. There is concern for serious toxicity, hospitalization, or sedation that could reduce her remaining alert time. If chemotherapy is canceled, her headaches and neurologic symptoms are expected to worsen within weeks despite steroids and opioids. The drug is compounded off-site in a fixed dose and must be authorized today. It cannot be delayed, modified, or replaced in time. The hospital is experiencing a temporary shortage of this medication. Palliative care is already involved either way. Hospital policy and state law allow either proceeding or canceling in this setting.

choice_1.choice: Proceed with the scheduled chemotherapy infusion.

choice_2.choice: Cancel chemotherapy and continue symptom-focused care only.
